Tuesday, Aug. 27 from 3 to 7 p.m.: Community table at Fairwood Farmersâ Market. Fundraiser for Mobius science kits for Holmes 3rd and 5th graders. Two shifts planned during the market hours. Some members are needed at 12:30 p.m. for set-up. Use Sign Up Genius.

Changes due for new school year

A new school year means fewer students in Spokane schools and ever-younger classmates, Holmes Elementary Principal Kale Colyar says.

Colyar described the changes as about 15 Spokane-North Rotary members quickly filled the Holmes supply closet on Aug. 19.

âThank you. Your help means the world to us,â Colyar said. He thanked the group for providing a new washing machine and dryer and for funding the supplies and helping stock the school products.

Due to a newly scheduled District meeting, he had only a few minutes to talk about the new school year, Colyar offered some details.

With a declining birth population, schools everywhere are dealing with reduced enrollments. In Seattle, for example, some 20 schools are planned to be closed. Spokaneâs District 81 expects 29,000 or fewer students, about 1,000 less than previous years.

Colyar said Holmes expects to have 380 students, about 20 fewer than in previous years.

But a big change is enrolling 4-year and 5-year old pre-school students, he said. âAnd we donât have pre-school certificated teachers yet,â he said.

Colyar said Holmes also will have 71 kindergartners, requiring a fourth class, and hiring another teacher for the younger students.

Colyar said Holmes again expects âabout a 45 percent mobility rate,â meaning the number of departing and arriving students during the school year.

Holiday times, like Halloween and the Christmas weeks are times when most students leave or arrive, he said.

Sandy Fink, the clubâs coordinator with Holmes, again headed the annual supply project.

The supply closet sundries included stacking cartons of rows of Clorox disinfecting wipes, which seemed enough to clean up any needs.

Sandy also mentioned a new product â âsentence stripsâ â will help reading and writing skills.

Colyar thanked the club for Spokane-Northâs long time commitment to Holmes and to the supply closet project, which began two principalâs ago before his tenure at the school.

Also Supplied were: Pencil Sharpeners and Post it Easel pads

Bulletin editors: Chuck Rehberg and Sandy Fink.

.

Helping women to better, safer lives

Spokane has long wrestled with issues of homelessness and domestic abuse of women and children.

Among the most prominent organization offering some help is Transitions. Founded by four groups of Catholic Sisters, Transitions has developed into a comprehensive program to provide needed help.

At the clubâs Aug. 12 luncheon, Transitions Development Director Jessica Burke described the history and activities.

In 1986 the nuns established Miryamâs House a residential program for women recovering from homelessness and abuse.

Following that were The Womenâs Drop-In Center in 1991; the Transitional Living Center and EduCare in 1993; the New Leaf Kitchen and CafÃ© in 2006; and, the Home Yard Cottages in 2018.

While the needs are big, many of the groups are small, Burke said.

Miryamâs has space for 9 women without children. The TLC, for homeless women and children, has 16 apartments and one permanent housing unit. Finding housing is difficult she said, adding many of the clients can stay 12 to 16 months, and âwe want less than two years.â

The larger Home Yard Cottages, for families and individuals, have 24 units, ranging from studio size to three bedrooms with 700 square feet, Burke said.

EduCare has licensed childcare and the TLC has infants, toddlers and pre-school kids who are homeless and recovering from trauma.

The New Leaf Kitchen helps women with hands-on training. âSome did not even know how to make coffee,â she said.

At the Womenâs Hearth, women have access to phones, computer, healthy food, hygiene supplies and showers.

The extensive âneeds listâ for the various programs include bus passes, diapers, cleaning products, cookware, towels, school supplies and various types of clothing.

As for the mounting needs at Transitions, Burke said âlast year 1,100 women were served and we passed that this year in July.â

As development director, Burke writes all of the grants. Transitions fund drives include the 22nd Annual People Who Care event Oct. 15 at the Davenport Grand, plus a âSpokane Mardi Brasâ program with Volunteers of America, and Giving Tuesdays and Give BIG initiatives.

Burke said the Transitions clientele has challenges, citing one case where law enforcement was called in an abusive instance where a murder was involved.

Asked why local abusive cases are so high, she said, âwho knows?â She added that area widespread poverty levels are part of the problem.

Though the numbers of nuns have declined since the founding of Miryamâs in 1986, the ladies leading Transitions have filled some of the needs and the motto âMoving Lives Forwardâ still applies.

Bulletin editors: Chuck Rehberg and Sandy Fink.

Welcome, Amy Jo

Club President Nancy Hanson said the board has approved the membership of Amy Jo Carlson. A formal introduction is planned.

Hillyard is now âin the ZONEâ

Northeast Spokane now has an aggressive new plan to develop the area of quality of life of social, health, education and recreational needs.

The theme is âYou Belong Hereâ in the Northeast Community Center ZONE.

At the Aug. 5 club luncheon, Jene Ray described the challenges and the ambitious plans in the neighborhoods of Hillyard and nearby environs.

Ray, a 2022 graduate of Leadership Spokane, was a classroom teacher for 20 years, then spent five years in Olympia, advocating for student-centered policies and funding pre-school through workforce development. She then directed operations for an educational research center at UW-Tacoma. Since 2018 she has supported the Northeast ZONE, modeled after the Harlem Childrenâs Zone.

As she discussed the plans, Jene walked about the packed Barkâs conference room, effectively circulating to reach all attending. Jerry Logan, a former education professor, said Jene looked like a kindergarten class making sure every student gets some attention.

Ray also is a founding member of Lumen School, Spokaneâs high school whose class members have their own kids. Our club sponsors a Lumen scholarship annually.

Jene circulated a small map outlining the Northeast neighborhood areas and schools âHillyard, Shiloh Hills, Whitman, Bemiss Nevada Heights, Minnehaha, and Chief Garry â where elementary schools funnel into Shaw, Garry and Yasuhara middle schools and then into Rogers High. She added some Holmes Elementary students also reach the ZONE.

Why create the ZONE?

Ray said the area was focused on Shaw, where she said âstudents just were not ready for the next level.â Jene said the Harlem Zone was âan Obama-eraâ programâ which âlooks at all the aspects of being a student.â

Thus the ZONE wants to work âwith residents, schools and organizations, assuring children and youth are safe and nurtured, residents are engages and all families have what they need to thrive.â

Using an array of grants and other sources, Ray said some 17,000 families have been served at the Northeast Center and 77,000 hours of after school and summer programs have been provided.

Some 12,500 hours of adult participation, especially for seniors, have been programmed, including fitness classes. Pets can be vaccinated and farmerâs markets and more than 10,000 books have been provided at the center.

On the plus side, she said Shawâs building has been remodeled, the adjacent community center has been improved. Multi-Care now provides mental health in the old Hillyard Library and dental care is âa mustâ at the center.

Busy Cook Street has been âcalmingâ with $1 million improvements and neighboring streets are safer, but intruders still pose problems.

Another challenge is dealing with the North Spokane Corridor freeway. Ray said some neighborhoods east of the road âare just dirt streets,â and though a walking bridge now spans the railroad tracks and freeway, she said many parents say itâs too tough for kids to get to the community center.

Another problem is finding affordable housing for families. Many families have several children and need three or four bedrooms. Also, English is a second language for some.

So, will a Harlem project work in Hillyard?

All in the Northeast Community Center hope the ZONE may be one of the answers

Bulletin editors: Chuck Rehberg and Sandy Fink. Photo by Lenore Romney.

Bite2Go -- Tom Stevenson

Club foundation c

hair John Mailliard mentioned that part of RIâs donated funds go to districts like our 5080 unit. He talked about a California club which helped support a water project in northern India and whose club president actually worked out a diplomatic solution to a boundary dispute there.

Hunger doesnât take weekends off

While most schools provide free meals for impoverished kids, summer time and weekends pose a problem.

Bite2Go sponsors a network to help.

At the clubâs July 29 luncheon, Tom Stevenson described the program.

âI didnât realize the level of poverty,â he said, adding, â82 percent of students in Spokane get free meals at school.â

Stevenson, a retired partner at Moss Adams, said he and fellow accountant Bill Simer competed âin the pocket protector days.â

Now Tom is Spokane âchief relationship managerâ of At the Core, which âcreates opportunities for churches, businesses and civic groups to adopt a school and feed hungry kids over the weekend.â

At the Core works closely with Spokaneâs 2nd Harvest organization to coordinate nonperishable food for the kids when schools are not in session.

The local efforts in eastern Washington and North Idaho are aligned with Share Our Strength headquartered in Washington, D.C. In its âNo Kid Hungryâ national program some $134 million was spent last year feeding hungry kids.

That group, founded 40 years ago, also helps with disaster relief and is now expanding to parts of India.

In the Spokane area, Stevenson said 11,395 students in classes from kindergarten to high schools were provided food on weekends and elsewhere. Some 250 groups have sponsored schools including Stevens County and Pasco schools and some in North Idaho.

Life Center Church has adopted Holmes Elementary Schoolâs Bite2Go program. Tom said Glover Middle School still needs a sponsor in our area.

Bite2Go, Tom said, âis great for the kids, but also for the businesses and other organizations. Rotary involvement, he said, includes Club 21, Aurora Northwest, South and some in the Tri-Cities.

He said groups pay $15 a week for elementary schools and $24 a week for middle schools.

Tom said on Tuesdays and Thursdays groups of 60 gather in a building next to 2nd Harvest and fill the bags âof real food, not just snacksâ to distribute.

One of the videos Tom showed said âone in five kids in America live in food insecurity.â

Bite2Go wants to keep taking a bite out of that problem.

As Tom says: âKids can change the world â if they are fed.â

Bulletin editors: Chuck Rehberg and Sandy Fink.

Saling Scholarship Award - Payton Nachtigal

Payton is a special Saling scholar

This yearâs Saling Scholarship winner has a variety of skills and interests.

At the clubâs July 22 luncheon, we learned that Payton Nachtigal rides horses, shoots well, works with goats and is mastering sign language.

Payton and her family live on a 300 acre ranch near Davenport. Her mom, Robin, joined the lunch along with Christine DeGeare, scholarship and alumni relations manager for the Community Colleges of Spokane Foundation.

Club Scholarship Chairman Jerry Logan introduced the program and the $1,500 scholarship award for this year and again next year. The program has shifted from graduating high school students to community college students.

DeGeare said her office received 742 student scholarship applicants. Ten finalists were selected for the Saling award, named for the late Jerry Saling, long-time club member, former state legislator and former Community Colleges of Spokane president.

DeGeare, who works at the collegesâ downtown office, said even with those applications many students still are not aware of the various scholarships available. In response to a question, Christine said she is willing to work with the club in incorporate concepts of Rotaryâs 4-Way Test in the clubâs application process.

In her application, Payton wrote about her familyâs 25 horses and the other animals on the farm. She has her own herd of Champion Boer Market goats. She was active in 4H, FFA and high school rodeo. She graduated with a 3.8 GPA while earning six varsity letters in softball, volleyball, cheerleading and band.

Payton qualified three times to the National High School Rodeo and seven times to the Silverstate International Rodeo. She is still active in barrel racing and breakaway roping events.

Jerry Logan said âPayton is an Annie Oakley, citing her shooting awards and working with horses.â

And she accomplished all of this while working through a learning disability.

In her application, Payton wrote, âIn kindergarten, a teacher realized that I learn differently than other students. I have a learning disability and we spent the next 12 years devising a learning system that worked best for me.â She achieved a 3.6 GPA at SFCC and plans to graduate next June.

At the club, Payton said she would like to work in an elementary or middle school as a teacher or para-professional educator specializing in American Sign Language.

Asked on her application about financial need, Payton responded that âher dad is in a wheelchair and is a C1 quadriplegic after his car was hit by a drunk driver. He struggles every day to do the simple things in life.â

Her mom works at a medical supply company.

Payton added: âI want to make a difference for students who are enrolled in schoolsâ special needs programs.

âMy learning disability has taught me to never give up and to try my best at everything I do, and that sometimes a person just has to look a different path to reach their goals in life.â

Bulletin editors: Chuck Rehberg and Sandy Fink.

Affair

Jump for âJoyaâ at its new site

With a new name and a much larger new space, Joya, Spokaneâs remarkable pediatric therapy provider has nearly doubled its ability to help infants and young children.

Founded in 1960 as the Spokane Guildsâ School & Neuromuscular Center, the organization has helped thousands of children in Spokane County ages 0 to 3 in need of therapy and special education services.

At the July 15 club luncheon, Teresa Conway, Joya grants and communications manager, recalled the history and new developments for the institution.

Conwayâs story is personal. Her son, James, she said had a normal birth but at age 3 months got pneumonia and needed help. The Guildsâ School staff was there to help.

Results like her case, she said, âis a gut check. Parents are frightened.â In some cases, she added, special child care costs often exceed $1 million to cover uncompensated care.

To raise funds the organization started collecting pennies. Annual âKid for Kids Penney Driveâ projects were familiar. The late Bill Hiatt of our club made it a Spokane-North project to help count the change every spring.

Conway discussed how the Guildsâ School was founded in 1960 by several women working in the Cowley Youth Building at Westminister Church, 411 S. Washington, to arrange assessment, therapy, education and support for the children and their families.

After 22 years, as the program grew, the Guildsâ School was located in 1982 in a former School District 81 elementary student at 2118 W. Garland, under long-time director Dick Boysen. He worked with the program for 42 years, retiring as executive director.

Conway said in 2017 land was purchased from a former convent at 1016 N. Superior. The expanded facility, which opened in spring of 2022, allows growth and access to the freeway and to the University District staff and students.

The name was rebranded to âJoya,â which means âgemâ in Spanish. It also connotes the joy of infants and young children who have grown through the program.

She said children served increased from 352 in 2022-23 to 509 last year. Conway said, â50 percent of the children served reached age-appropriate milestones and did not require additional services after Joya.â She added that 486 parents and guardians received training to help aid in the child development last year.

Joya also has 15 clinical rotations, 5 special education practicums and 13 medicine and physiatry residents, among the staff support. This year 9 pediatric medical residency rotations will be started.

Joya still collects pennies, but last year is secured a $3 million federal grant for neurodevelopmental research and training.

Conway said financial elements are âin thirds â one-third state and federal disability act money, one-third in philanthropy and one-third in private insurance.â

Joya, starting with all those pennies, and other help, indeed has become a âgemâ in Spokane health care for infant and children and their parents.

Bulletin editors: Chuck Rehberg and Sandy Fink.

Golden Hero Awards

Ron Noble, Sheila Fritts and Jessica Shew joined the Holmes staff and students for the final Golden Hero Awards of this school year -- thanks to them!

Little pantries fill a big need

Hundreds of hungry patrons line up, sometimes daily for Little Free Pantries in Spokane.

Unlike cart-filled grocery bags, most pantry patrons take only a few items to get through the day, Mary Charbonneau, a long-time volunteer, told club members at the July 8 luncheon.

The pantry idea started as an off-shoot of the little free library books concept, filled with small covered cabinets on posts, she said.

Now dozens of small cabinets are filled with non-perishable food items in low-income neighborhoods throughout Spokane and the Spokane Valley. âWe now have 68 free pantries and all are very busy,â Charbonneau said. She also wants to add sites in the West Plains area.

She said a wide assortment of folks have built little free pantries, including Girl Scouts and Boy Scouts. A Great Family Project site distributes how-to building kits with patterns and assembly tips. Food items come from a variety of sources including large food banks.

At the luncheon she showed a small grocery bag with her âtop five items,â including dry cereal, canned fish, a chicken m eat pouch, a banana and a jar of peanut butter (âthe top favorite.â). Spaghetti and sauce also are popular, because the dishes can last several days, she added.

The free pantry idea started several years ago, spurred nation-wide by the pandemic in 2020, Charbonneau said.

She said a statewide survey shows that in Spokane County 49 percent are struggling to get adequate food, adding, â56 percent of those households have kids in the home.â One website added that â29 percent of those experiencing food insecurity do not qualify for federal nutrition programs.â

Mary & Paul's Little Pantry

With the help of her husband, Bill, she said up to 250 pounds a day and 100 users are distributed at her pantry near Monroe and Montgomery. Bill, using their pickup, loads about 500 pounds of items weekly to that little pantry.

Mary said each little free pantry has a âsteward,â who monitors the site. She said 40 to 50 stewards meet monthly to share ideas.

The littlefreepantrySpokane.org site, created two years ago, has 4,100 members and lists the pantry âno-nos,â including no medicines or vitamins and no glass items.

The site adds: âStay on topic. No politics. No irrelevant shared links. No food deliveries and no pictures with permission.â

The Spokane free pantry site also adds:

âSharing food is more than nourishment; itâs a profound act of generosity and connection.

âItâs a reminder that amidst our differences, we all hunger for kindness and community.â

Expo â74 Memories -- Mike Kobluk

Spokane-North Rotary Club

Happy Buck$:

John Mailliard was happy to note his 24th anniversary with the FBI. J. Edgar Hoover administered Johnâs oath of office.

Announcements:

Club members are still welcome to join the Rotary table from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. May 18 as part of the 50th anniversary of Expo â74. The table will be near the Rotary Fountain in Riverfront Park. Weâll have a sign-up sheet at our meeting next Monday.

World-class memories remembered

The theme for the clubâs April 29 luncheon clearly was âThanks for the Memories.â

As the 50th anniversary of Spokaneâs Expo â74 Worldâs Fair, Mike Kobluk, hired in 1972 as manager of special events for Expo, talked about the amazing roster of performances throughout the six-month fair.

Kobluk, quickly then named manager of performance and visual events for the fair, said that when challenges mounted to get top-rated stars to attend Expo it was comedian Bob Hope who made a key difference.

Koblukâs talk was titled âExpo Memoriesâ and Hopeâs longtime signature song was of course âThanks for the Memories.â

And when Hope delivered, the trickle of stars opened the floodgates of first-class events.

Kobluk said dozens of acts remained interested, but un-signed, for the small inland Northwest city.

But when Hope not only agreed to perform, and also starred in a television ad saying he would attend, suddenly top performers agreed, Kobluk said.

Suddenly, he added, Expo, which some feared would be like âa three-week county fairâ to what The Spokane Daily Chronicle called it âthe center of entertainment for six months.â

At the lunch, Kobluk distributed a list of more than 100 attractions that came to Expo â74.

The diverse acts included the Seattle Operaâs âAida,â Bachman-Turner Overdrive, Harry Belafonte, Jack Benny, the Carpenters, Chicago, the Cleveland Orchestra, Rita Coolidge and Kris Kristofferson, Ella Fitzgerald, Festa Brazil, Margot Fonteyn and the London Ballet, Merle Haggard, Bob Hope of course, the Irish Rovers, gymnast Olga Korbut, the Joffrey City Centre Ballet, Liberace, Gordon Lightfoot, The Limelighters with Glenn Yarbrough, and the 100-plus member Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra with Zubin Mehta.

The list continued with mime Marcel Marceau, Russiaâs Moiseyev Dance Company, Spokane-native opera singer Patrice Munsel, Jim Nabors, Itzhak Perlman, Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra, Buck Owens, Roberta Peters, Charley Pride, the Pointer Sisters, Helen Reddy, the Royal Shakespeare Theatre, Seals & Croft, Isaac Stern, Van Cliburn, ballet dancer Edward Villella, Walt Wagner, Porter Wagoner, Lawrence Welk, Roger Williams and the Royal Lipizzaner Stallions.

Sports fans also enjoyed the Soviet National Basketball Team, the Soviet Championship Skaters, Rodeo and Wild West Shows, the Seattle Supersonics, a pre-season NFL game with the New England Patriots and Denver Broncos, and the WSU-Kansas football game.

With that lineup, that âcenter of entertainmentâ claim was realized.

Kobluk said âit was a real miracleâ that the tangle of railroads from Trent (now Spokane Falls Blvd.) north to the Spokane River was removed quickly enough to open the space which now covers Riverfront Park.

He said a bit of lucky confusion made that happen. While a Spokane delegation went to Chicago to ask a railroad executive to clear the tracks, Lincoln Savings president Roderick A. âRodâ Lindsay, Expo board chairman, announced the group. A secretary carried the message and the railroad leader came out, expecting his long-time friend, then New York City Mayor John Lindsay.

After the confusion was cleared up, the railroad leader said, while you are here, come on in. And soon the railroad agreed to move the obstacles, clearing the space for Expo.

Kobluk, one of the original members of the Chad Mitchell Trio from Spokane, used all of his contacts to lure entertainers to come to Spokane.

âI wrote to all the mayors I could find to invite cultural events, bands, singers, whatever.â He said some 450 groups paid their own to provide free entertainment on site.

The Smithsonian was asked to provide folk-life events. They declined, but Bob Glatzer, of the Smithsonian staff, liked the ideas and stayed to coordinate during the fair, and stayed.

Club member Art Rudd, a friend of Glatzer, said he bought one of the small houses at folk life for a kidsâ play houseâ¦and the building is still used in his yard.

Asked about how Spokane could hurdle all the challenges to make Expo possible, Kobluk said, âKing Cole, called âthe father of Expo,â would not take ânoâ for an answer.â

The challenges also included finding a funding measure when a local 60 percent super levy failed by just a few votes, plus a national gasoline shortage which lower interstate speeds to 50 miles per hour.

When a flood of entertainers flowed in Kobluk said hotels were filled, especially for some larger groups. Jack Geraghty, working with Expo prior to being Spokane mayor, found interesting lodging. A Winnebago franchise in Liberty Lake had a lot-full of recreational vehicles. The RVs were used as hotel rooms, two or four to a unit.

âExpo had to buy blankets, soap and other items, but the visitorsâ unique spaces loved it,â Kobluk said.

He said when plans for the state of Washington pavilion were discussed some wanted a planetarium and others wanted an aquarium. But the winners were an Opera House and a new convention center.

Given all the entertainers who came, it would have been hard not to have a new 2,000-seat Opera House for performances.

After Expo, Kobluk was named by the city to direct activities at the Opera House, Coliseum and Albi Stadium. He led those facilities for more than 30 years. In 1995 the Spokane Veterans Arena replaced the Coliseum, more than 100,000 square feet of convention center space was added and now Albi has been replaced by the new ONE Spokane Stadium downtown.

And Expoâs legacy--Riverfront Parkâhas become a world-class downtown venue.

Especially for the next nine weeks we can think about the 50th Anniversary and what Expo produced.

Those are enduring memories indeed.

Rod Tamura - Japanese incarceration impacts on the Tamura and Oba families.

Calendar:

Melinda, a Realtor, has worked with Jessica through Idaho Central Bank. Melinda said Jessica has three children and likes to travel and drink some wine.

Club President Simer said the board has a goal of adding five new members â Jessica is the first â by Sept. 30.

WWII âcampâ lessons recalled

Casualties of war come in varieties of ways.

And while hostilities continued overseas, for Japanese Americans in the USA, the dreaded words at home for Japanese Americans were âincarcerationâ and âinternment.â

Rod Tamura said itâs important not to forget the impacts on those affected.

At the April 22 luncheon, Tamura, now retiring from a career with Spokane schools, brought a large plastic bin of family memories. There were pictures of the Tamuras, his dadâs family, and Obas, his momâs family. He shared slides, yearbooks, documents, maps and many stories.

Many of the pictures showed conditions in the barren landscapes of Minidoka in southern Idaho and in Tule Lake, Calif., near the Oregon border.

Two months after Pearl Harbor, President Franklin Roosevelt issued Executive Order 9066, forcing tens of thousands of Japanese in America and Japanese Americans to abandon farms and businesses. They were boarded on buses with blackened windows as they moved inland to make-shift lodgings, former stables and other residences often ringed with barbed wire.

Tamura, now nearly 64, wants to continue retelling his familyâs ordeal, especially to teens who get just glimpses of this part of history.

Rod, raised in Spokane, said he himself âdidnât know much about the internments until he was in high school,â adding, âmom didnât want to talk about it.â

He said the ordeals for Japanese Americans âoften are glossed overâ in history lessons, so he has developed a 45-minute presentation to share his familiesâ stories.

Rod learned that until 1875 most Asians had no citizenship rights. During internments during World War II most rights were suspended.

Much of his story involves the Minidoka War Relocation Center in Hunt, Idaho, in Jerome County in south central Idaho. The camp housed more than 13,000 from the February 1942 opening until its closure on Oct. 28, 1945. Minidoka was one of 10 internment camps.

Tamura said he visited Minidoka just before Covid, saying, âOh, my God. It blew my mind.â

His family had a farm on 194 acres in Kent, Wash., but often land then could only be leased, not owned.

During the internments, some ancestors here lodged at the Puyallup Fairgrounds, called âCamp Harmony,â but housed in former stables. Curfew there was 9 p.m. and lights out at 10 p.m., Tamura said.

At Minidoka, he said, there were 44 blocks of housing in 12 wood-framed barracks, some with just black tar paper sides, and the cold winds âswept in and sand got into everything.â Pot-bellied stoves provided the only heat. Tamura showed a picture of the guard tower, which looked inward on the residents.

The camp had two elementary schools, one junior high and one high school.

Players could play baseball on a dirt field, and Rod showed pictures of his dad in uniforms in the mid-1930s. The irony of Americaâs past-time is a long way from Ichiro Suzukiâs pending Hall of Fame notoriety and Shohei Otaniâs multi-million wealth as baseballâs wealthiest player.

Filed say 844 residents who were incarcerated at Minidoka volunteered or were drafted for military service, including William K. Nakamura, a Medal of Honor Army soldier.

A national monument for Minidoka was approved in 2001.

After retirement, he said he will continue his history lessons about the internments, especially to the young.

During the internment, much of the land and many businesses were confiscated. It took decades to get any reparations. In 2006, President Bush approved $38 million divided for all 10 camps.

As club members Eric Johnson and Ron Noble mentioned during Tamuraâs talk, Yakama Tribal members did return some of the property reclaimed to Japanese Americans in the Yakima Valleyâanother irony as so many Indian Americans were forced onto reservation lands.

Tamura asked his dad about returning to farming after the internments, but his dad told him âno, farming is a hard life.â

Rod said internees were sent to the camps âif people had just 1/32nd Japanese blood.â

A national aid he will continue his history lessons about the internments, especially to the young.

His lessons: âBe respectful and appreciate the rights you have because things can change.â

âAnd we have to be care about what other groups are like.â

North Notes

Spokane-North Rotary Club

April 15, 2024

Calendar:

April 29: Noon meeting at the Bark. Speaker: Mike Kobluk, Expo 74 50th anniversary memories.

Happy Buck$:

John Mailliard added âa coupla bucksâ to honor the woman with the most Oscar wins â costume designer Edith Head.

.

Happy Birthday: Sandy Finkâs happy day is on April 20.

Lawyers should help rebuild trust

In the past 20 years, public trust has waned in many areas from the presidency to law enforcement to the legal profession, Hunter M. Abell told club members at the April 15 luncheon.

Abell said âcynicism and nostalgiaâ are among the reasons for the decline of respect for many sectors of business.

âThere are simple answers, but not easy answers,â he said.

He said as polarization has mounted âlawyers, whose number one role is the guardian of structures, should become teachers.â

Abell, on a leave as president of the Washington State Bar Association, has had his own remarkable journey.

He was born on a ranch near Inchelium on the Colville Reservation.

Part of his legal practice, he said, is split between working âon a table in Incheliumâ and in Spokane at the Williams Kastner offices. The firm also has offices in Seattle and Portland.

Abell specializes in civil litigation, residential real estate and Indian law.

He served as a commander in the Navyâs JAG Corps and was a liaison officer in the Central Criminal Court in Baghdad, Iraq.

Abell graduated in Willam and Mary, earned his law degree at Gonzaga in 2005 and studied at Georgetown Law in 2006. He also is a member of the Ferry County and King County bar associations.

So, obviously, Abell brings a lot to the table when he talks about the roles of lawyers.

At the luncheon, he used slides to show how much public confidence has declined in sectors.

Polling showed respect for the Presidency dropped from 52 percent in 1973 to just 26 percent last year. Supreme Court showed 45 percent in 1973; just 27 percent in 2023. Banking went from 60 percent in 1979 to 26 percent last year. Public school trust dropped from 58 percent in 1973 to 26 percent and media fell from 39 percent to 18 percent. Congressâ numbers dropped from 42 percent to just 8 percent.

Abell said the only growth in respect in the sectors in the polling was the military, which grew from 58 percent in 1973 to 60 percent last year. He added though, depending on war time, in some years even the military declined 7 percent.

While many reasons have âundermined public trust,â he said, âtrust can be rebuilt.â

He challenges lawyers to help rally trust in many areas and institutions.

Though some may think there are too many lawyers, Abell said âwe need more lawyers, especially in rural areas.â

He added that we also need more doctors and nurses and accountants in rural areas, but people in urban areas, especially the young, donât like to move to rural areas. âThere is no big dating pool in rural areas,â he quipped.

Abell said another key to rebuilding trust among institutions is to make an effort to connect better with people in the areas. He said Rotary, with its various classifications is âwell-positioned with its diversity.â Reaching young people is a special challenge, he admits.

Asked about the possibility that some new lawyers now may be admitted to the bar without bar exams, Abell said he hopes that does not become areas where there is a âgold standardâ for those who passed the bar exam, and a âsilver standardâ for those who just clerked with law offices to be admitted.

A gift of giving back

Rick Clark didnât wear a backpack to our April 8 luncheon, but thatâs because he probably gave it away to a needy person on the way to the Bark.

What he never gives away is his will to help people in need.

Clark nearly teared-up as he recalled his challenges and successes. His riveting life story also brought strong emotions to the full crowd.

Clark, now 53, was born in the Spokane Valley. Dad left early, leaving poverty and numerous challenges for the family. He said he dropped out of high school and already had a baby. His sisters also had babies by then.

Rick said by age 44 âhis third marriage was on the rocks,â had five children and 50 different jobs âall entry-level.â By then he was âsquatting in a trailer in Medical Lake.â

Emotions raw, Clark said he screamed, saying âyouâre not going out like this.â

âI wasnât a bad guy, but I just didnât want things that way,â he said.

âI was 28 years as a drop out and this was my âHail Maryâ shotâ to do something, Clark said.

Thatâs where he met Jerrod. Clark had gone to the downtown bus plaza and saw Jerrod, dirty clothing, no shoes. âHe looked like one of my sonâs age,â Rick said.

So Clark made a connection to someone âwho was doing worse than me.â

Jerrod told him he had slept under the Monroe Street Bridge the previous night and muggers took his backpack and most of his meager belongings.

Rick offered the question which he now knows connects people most: âAre you hungry?â

Clark offered his $10 at the plaza food court. Jerrod wanted a pastry and a Mountain Dew.

Rick wrote down Jerrodâs clothing sizes, a backpack, and promised to find him again.

âYou are low, but others are even lower and my job is I want to be a helper,â Rick said.

He gave out a backpacks and started at Spokane Community College. Rick graduated the same day his son graduated from Spokane Falls Community College.

Buoyed by that success he borrowed $100 and sent a heartfelt letter about his travails to Gonzaga University.

âThis opened the door to ending his chain of poverty,â Clark said. He said at GU classes, he was in his 50s and one student in his 30s and they used to nod at each other since every other student was so much younger.

GU provided $35,000 to start school and a donor paid most of the rest.

With his communications degree in hand, Clark started out to help âGiving Back Pack.â More than 7,000 backpacks, with toiletries, clothing and other essential items were given to the needy.

When the backpack needs were met, Clark changed the program to âGiving Back Spokane,â and the non-profit provides a variety of necessities and food, especially for youngsters in need who may not have food when schools are not in session.

Because all the money is private community funds, no governmental red tape limits donations, he said.

During the Covid pandemic, Clark said, the group helped 110 restaurants keep open.

Talking about the homeless, here and elsewhere, Rick said the key âis to make a connection. When there is no hate, there is dignity,â he said. âGive people a reason to get up in the morning.â

He said his Facebook responses have numbered 36,000â¦âand 80 percent are people over age 40.â

Clark said he did find Jerrod a few years ago, finally recognized as schizophrenic, living in North Idaho.

And Rick Clark, whose life has gone very far indeed, now operates his agency on West Sprague, just a block or so from that bus plaza where his life changed forever.

No fooling, itâs tax time

One of the first things Michael Baumgartner mentioned is the distinction about who raises taxes in Spokane County.

âI am the treasurer, not the county assessor,â he told the April 1 club luncheon. âI am your banker. The assessor adjusts the rates for levies and bonds.â

Mike, who was elected treasurer in 2018, was joined at the lunch with Hillary Pham, the county treasurerâs inter-governmental affairs officer.

While Mike knows very well about the distinctions about raising taxes, he has much to talk about how those rates have risen, especially for schools, while he was in the State Senate from 2010 to 2018.

He said the Democratic legislative majority and the governor, also a Democrat, helped push teacher salaries âto the highest in the nation.â He added that with smaller class loads statewide, âthere are also some very expensive new buildings.â

Mike and wife, Eleanor, know personally about public schools, since four of their five children are in school.

Baumgartner shared how the growth of Spokane County property taxes raised during his term: $579 million in 2019; $658 million, in 2020; $713 million in 2021; $770 million in 2022; $818 million in 2023 and $856 million in 2024. That is an increase of $277 million from 2019.

He said about 60 percent of the taxes fund public K-12 education, including salaries and buildings, and 40 percent of tax bills are self-imposed by tax payers for school bonds and levies.

The treasurerâs management team, including Pham and six others, supervise banking services for 80 local government entities and a $1.9 billion portfolio. Using an array of U.S. Treasury notes, Fannie Mac, Fannie Mae, World Bank and corporate bonds, he said more than $120 million in earnings have accrued since 2019 tax years.

He said the Treasurer's office also has been able to speed funding for projects like the expensive Bigelow Gulch widening.

Baumgartner said the increasing tax rate does hit hard for some homeowners, especially seniors on fixed-rate incomes. Last year senior and disabled property tax exemptions went to 10,595 participants, 1,000 more than in 2022.

âSome people come to our office with tears in their eyes because they canât pay their taxes,â he said.

To keep the access, he said, a City of Spokane Valley office and several other collection points are opened during spring and fall tax deadline times.

Asked how his office has worked with five commissioners rather than three, Baumgartner said he probably would have liked a county executive system to help manage the load.

He also was asked about his candidacy for the 5th District Congressional seat where long-term Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers said she will not seek re-election.

Baumgartner, 48, is a Pullman native. His mom was an elementary teacher and his dad a professor at WSU. Mike has a major in economics and minors in French and math at WSU and a masterâs degree in public administration from Harvard.

He met Eleanor while working in Afghanistan and Mike worked there and in the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad in strategic planning.

He said he would like to get involved in international issues and said he has talked with Cathy about âhow much could get done in four years,â telling him that much could be done.

But for now Mike reminds property owners that first-half county taxes are due April 30.

An active home sales spring is expected in Spokane, and while prices continue to rise, homes are even pricier elsewhere.

Another Realtor index expects a 3.6 percent gain in units, but a 10.2 percent price drop, while the National Association of Realtors forecast a 13.5 percent increase, with no overall increase in prices.

He said in February the median home sales price was $400,000, up 6.7 percent and closed sales totaled 341, a 13 percent increase.

âThere are about 1,000 homes on the market and the âchurnâ has been pretty good,â Eric said.

He said a number of home buyers are moving to Spokane. âThey are coming from L.A., Portland, Seattle, and even Coeur dâAlene, where costs are pricing out of that market. âThe Spokane Valley is the benefit of that,â Eric said.

Inventory is low, he said, and, with prices rising, some new âruthless buildersâ are cutting quality, like not installing soffits, and locating on just 5-foot-wide setbacks.

He said, with âa lot of variables,â some younger people are âmore of a rental mind,â rather than buying homes.

But overall, Johnson said, âThis is not a bad market for home sales,â even when interest rates âhas been the most sensitive weâve ever had since I have been doing this.â

Next Tuesday voters decide funding

Millions of dollars are at stake Feb. 13 as residents of 15 Spokane area school districts vote on bonds and levies.

At the Feb. 5 luncheon members learned details about the funding proposals in Spokaneâs District 81 from Shawn Jordan, chief operations officer and Sandra Jarrard, chief of communications and governmental affairs.

District 81 Superintendent Adam Swinyard, scheduled to speak, had a conflict.

Jordan was introduced by Sandy Fink, who was principal at North Central High School when Jordan was a teacher there.

For many years, the educators have recalled the mantra that âbonds are for buildings and levies are for learning.â Levy measures require 50 percent passage, while bond measures require 60 percent âsuper majoritiesâ and 40 percent of voters from the previous general election for validation.

Jordan said District 81 now has 29,000 students, an increase of 400 this year. He said the district has 5,037 employees. He added that students from 79 different languages are spoken in the district.

In each of three years, the District 81 replacement levy rate is assessed at $2.50 per $1,000 value. The current 3-year levies were assessed at $2.41 in 2022, $2.10 in 2023 and $2.24 this year.

Thus the amounts for the new levy rates would total $95 million in 2025, $99 million in 2026 and $103 million in 2027.

The levies supplement state funding, and the local money, Jordan said, funds athletics, arts, music and drama, nurses, counselors, advanced placement courses, special education, behavioral specialists, technology support, smaller class sizes, highly capable programs, librarians, custodians and intervention programs.

Jordan said average class load in most elementary schools is 18 students. Club member Jerry Logan, a retired educator, said âthatâs an optimum levelâ for success. School classes for grades 4 and 5 average 22 students and middle and high school classes average 25 students, he said.

The district has 57 buildings, including 34 elementary schools, 9 middle schools, 5 high schools and 7 schools dedicated to alternative learning.

Jordan said 2024 major bond projects include replacements of Adams and Madison elementaries, modernizing parts of North Central High and Garry Middle School, Chase Middle School improvements, upgrades to Public Montessori and Libby Center, Community School improvements and a full design of Balboa and Indian Trail elementaries. He said there is some discussion about locating a school in the Eagle Ridge area in the future.

The bond assessment per $1,000 value estimates are $1.34 in 2025, $1.36 in 2026 and $1.30 in 2039. The previous three year assessments were $2.11 in 2022, $1.70 in 2 023 and $1.58 this year.

Jarrard and Jordan said âWe have been going out to all groups to get the correct information out, but people are feeling the tax.â

Next Tuesday, area voters will decide the important pass-fail tests for school funding.

This center uses childâs play

to deal with abused and neglected kids

After long successful careers in higher education, Gordon and Sue Jackson now really like playing with kids and their toys.

Their real joy involves their volunteer work with the Vanessa Behan Childcare Center.

Gordon and Sue have retired after 32 years at Whitworth University. They came to Spokane from South Africa in 1983. Gordon led the journalism program and Sue worked in administrative jobs at Whitworth.

For the past 17 years, they have volunteered at Vanessa Behan. They shared their stories at the clubâs Jan. 29 luncheon.

Vanessa Kay Behan was a 2-year-old Spokane girl who died from a long list of injuries of child abuse. In 1987, the center was opened in a private home to provide safe care for neglected children. The need grew and the operation was moved to a South Hill location and now has been expanded to a spacious building and playground at 2230 E. Sprague.

The center operates 24 hours a day, 365 days a year and all services are free and confidential.

Children are cared for ages birth through 6 and on a case-by-case basis ages 7 to 12, the Jacksons said. Many kids are referred to the center, but some drop-ins can be accommodated, they said.

The center serves children of families âin cases of substance abuse, domestic violence, homelessness or just exhausted and worn out from the demands of parenting.â

In 1987, 427 children were cared for at the center. In 2023, 6,860 kids were protected, they said. Over that lifespan, they said, some 132,500 children were served. The center operates with a nearly $4 million operating budget. About half of the money is from individual and business contributions, augmented by events, programs and appeals and a few grants.

Gordon and Sue said they work 4-hour shifts twice a week, playing with infants and kids.

âIt is a very secure building and every door is locked,â Sue said.

âThere is an enormous, kid-friendly great room, with a climbing wall, slides and hidey-holes. Kids can run and they can build things,â she said, adding, there also are quiet transition places. An outdoor playground is designed for kid-friendly surfaces and equipment.

Gordon said the youngsters âare incredibly honest,â asking in various ways, âcan I trust you?â or âdo you like me?â

Sue said that âthere are some special need kids who are classified âone-onâ children who get single house parents.â

She added there is âa dramatic roomâ where kids ages 2-5 can play dress up and use instruments.

âWe both enjoy playing with the toys,â she said, displaying for the club a tall plastic pole with rings that curves around the stack.

Gordon said the Behan Center âhas very few male volunteers. We need more male role models.â

Preventing child abuse and dealing with neglect, unfortunately is a big challenge, but the Vanessa Behan staff and volunteers have made a huge difference.

Sheriff Nowels: âWe do have a planâ

At the Oct. 30 club luncheon, Spokane County Sheriff John Nowels offered dozens of reasons to support Measure No. 1 â building a new jail and several other item and programs.

While some critics have said the law and justice program measure lacks details, Nowels offered a blizzard of data points about how current correction facilities are overcrowded and outdated and programs for mental health and substance use disorders are severely lacking.

If ballot Measure 1 is approved by voters, a 0.2% sales tax over 30 years would generate an estimated $1.7 billion to build two new jails and provide local governments in the county to added revenue, which, by state law, must be spent on criminal justice, public safety and behavioral health programs.

The funding would split, with 60 percent â about $540 million, including interest payments, for the county, and 40 percent for various municipalities, Nowels said.

While some critics said the plan lacks details, Nowels said flatly, âWe do have a plan.â

âWe have lacked money for criminal justice for a long time,â the sheriff said.

With Measure 1, the current county jail would open and two new buildings near the old jail would be built. One would be a five-story jail for medium and minimum offenders. The second new building would house a variety of behavior programs, including detox programs, a drug court and community contact programs, Nowels said.

The existing jail would house maximum-level offenders.

The Geiger Corrections Center, a minimum-level facility built in the Korean War-era, would be demolished, the sheriff said. Geiger, he said, can only house 100 to 150 minimum-level inmates and only males because it lacks staffing and facilities. âThey could just climb the fence,â he said, adding the county intends to demolish Geiger in five years regardless of the ballot result. Replacing that could cost $40 million, he added.

Nowels said that the current jail is severely overcrowded. In one recent day, the jail, designed to house 465 inmates, had 675 inmates.

âSome days we have deputies in patrol cars holding inmates, waiting for a room in the jail to open,â he said. âItâs not anecdotal,â Nowels said, âWe have to make decisions every day about who to hold in jail or who to release.â

Building a facility for behavioral programs comes close to home for the sheriff.

He said his daughter has struggled with addiction. âWe must have a system that helps people. For many, a better health program is better than incarceration, but we just lack the facilities to do the programs,â Nowels said.

With the spread of fentanyl and cocaine and other substances, he said, âWe have an epidemic of drug use.â He said housing someone with a drug problem in jail for 30 to 90 days âcould be a better placeâ than on the streets. Space for that is lacking now.

Talking about homelessness, the sheriff said âOnly three people died because of freezing temperatures in Spokane last year, but 63 people died of drug overdoses.â

If Measure 1 passes, he said, construction would take five years to complete and add 500 beds to the total.

The sheriff said the new facilities can be built without adding much staff, because current state law limits how many inmates can be housed on one floor, while the new designs can use fewer staff per floor.

Nowels also detailed how local and state law enforcement ranks here are among the lowest totals in the nation. To achieve the average national number of officers, he said Spokane County would need to add 136 deputies.

âWe need more cops,â he said.

Betsy: âNegativity has never solved one thingâ

Talking about homelessness, crime and safety, campaigning and other topics, Spokane Council President candidate Betsy Wilkerson said, âThere is a lot of negativity â the worst since my time in Spokane.â

Asked about liberal and conservative views in the city mayoral and council administration, Wilkerson said âboth sides are a little guilty.â

âWe must take the personalities out to get the work done,â she said, adding, ânegativity has never solved one thing.â

Wilkerson spoke at the clubâs Oct. 23 meeting. Her opponent, Kim Plese, did not attend.

On Oct. 30, the last of the clubâs pre-election programs, Spokane County Sheriff John Nowels will discuss the proposal to fund a new jail.

Asked about the city council presidency, Wilkerson said âI was going to retire, but no one else will do it. Thatâs what leadership does.â Among other duties, the council president, she said, sets the council agenda and âis second in lineâ to the mayor.

Wilkerson was appointed as a District 2 Councilwoman in 2020 and re-elected in 2021. She was asked to run for president by former Council President Breean Beggs after he was named a Superior Court judge by Gov. Jay Inslee earlier this year.

Betsy has owned and operated Mooreâs Assisted Living, a mental health facility, since 1993. On the City Council she is current president of the Spokane Regional Transportation Council and current president of the Associated Washington Cities.

She fielded a variety of topics during the clubâs luncheon.

One thing she mentioned was âcracked sidewalks,â saying throughout town sidewalk problems make it difficult to travel, especially for those with disabilities. She said traffic calming money from red light fines could help.

About homelessness, Wilkerson said she was impressed with programs in Vancouver, Wash., to house âtiny homes and RVs.â That is a better solution than living in cars, she said, adding, "when you are homeless, you often live in a car.â

She commended Lt. Gov. Denny Heck for convening representatives statewide to study issues of homelessness âand how to stay at the table.â

âSince Covid, when there were few gatherings,â she said. âWe have to build back civic muscle.â

Wilkerson is no fan of concentrated homeless venues, such as Camp Hope and the East Trent Shelter. She said, â70 people you can absorb; but 300, no.â

She said space is available on city, county and state parcels of lands in the area and even private parking lots, including near churches. She suggests finding (the homeless) areas âwhere they grew up, such as Hillyard.â

âLetâs not make them come downtown,â she said. The area near Second and Division is a problem area because there is no place to gather. Apartments are secured. There is no park or benches and most businesses lock lavatories by 8 p.m.

She said some homeless people are moving to Deer Park, but facilities and programs are scarce there.
